title: 108_hr5131
content: The Act is titled the "Special Olympics Sport and Empowerment Act of 2004" and its purpose is outlined in the findings section. Special Olympics celebrates inclusivity and values individuals with intellectual disabilities. The organization aims to end isolation and stigma through sports training and competition for over 1.5 million athletes. Special Olympics provides competitive opportunities for 1,500,000 athletes with intellectual disabilities in 26 sports, aiming to expand participation globally. The organization has a positive impact on the quality of life for individuals with intellectual disabilities, improving health, confidence, and community integration. Special Olympics also serves as a platform for breaking down barriers, improving public health, and changing negative attitudes towards people with intellectual disabilities. The United States government strongly supports Special Olympics, recognizing its importance in improving the lives of individuals with intellectual disabilities. The purposes of this Act include increasing athlete participation, dispelling negative stereotypes, promoting family involvement in sports, and highlighting the gifts of people with intellectual disabilities. The United States government supports Special Olympics to improve the lives of individuals with intellectual disabilities. SEC. 3 provides assistance for Special Olympics. The Secretary of Education and the Secretary of State may provide grants or agreements to Special Olympics for education and international activities. This includes promoting expansion, increasing participation of individuals with disabilities, implementing education programs, and supporting volunteer programs. Activities to increase participation of individuals with intellectual disabilities in Special Olympics outside the United States and improve awareness of their abilities globally. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can award grants to Special Olympics for on-site health assessments, screening, education, data collection, and referrals to health services, coordinating with private providers and government programs. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can award grants to Special Olympics for on-site health assessments, screening, education, data collection, and referrals to health services, coordinating with private providers and government programs. Amounts appropriated for this purpose cannot be used for direct treatment of diseases, medical conditions, or mental health conditions, but this does not limit the use of non-Federal funds by Special Olympics. The application and annual report requirements are outlined in Section 4. To be eligible for funding, Special Olympics must submit an application with activities and measurable goals. Additionally, they must provide an annual report to receive funds. Special Olympics must submit an annual report to receive funds, detailing progress towards meeting goals outlined in their application. Authorization of appropriations for grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements under sections 3(a), 3(b), and 3(c) includes $5,500,000 for fiscal year 2005 with increasing amounts for the following years.
